profiledesc.creation: This finding aid was produced using ArchivesSpace on 2023-08-22 13:53:48 -0700.

did.abstract: Alan Mandell is an accomplished theater and film actor, theater manager, stage director, and producer. He was a founding member of the San Francisco Actor's Workshop and the San Quentin Drama Workshop, managed the Repertory Theatre of Lincoln Center, and was consulting director for the Los Angeles Actors' Theatre and the Los Angeles Theater Center where he ran the Poetry Literary Series. Mandell is considered to be a foremost interpreter and scholar of Samuel Beckett's works. Materials in this collection document Mandell's professional career and include scripts, photographs, some personal materials, and correspondence with many notable literary and theater figures, including Beckett.
did.physloc: Stored off-site. All requests to access special collections material must be made in advance using the request button located on this page.

accessrestrict.head: Restrictions on Access
accessrestrict.p: Open for research. All requests to access special collections materials must be made in advance using the request button located on this page.

userestrict.head: Restrictions on Use and Reproduction
userestrict.p: Property rights to the objects belong to UCLA Library Special Collections. All other rights, including copyright, are retained by the creators and their heirs. It is the responsibility of the researcher to determine who holds the copyright and pursue the copyright owner or his or her heir for permission to publish where The UC Regents do not hold the copyright.

phystech.head: Physical Characteristics and Technical Requirements
phystech.p: CONTAINS DIGITAL AND AUDIOVISUAL MATERIALS: This collection contains both processed and unprocessed digital and audiovisual materials. For information about the access status of the material that you are looking for, refer to the Physical Characteristics and Technical Requirements note at the series and file levels. All requests to access processed digital and audiovisual materials must be made in advance using the request button located on this page.

prefercite.head: Preferred Citation
prefercite.p: [Identification of item], Alan Mandell papers (Collection 2123). UCLA Library Special Collections, Charles E. Young Research Library, University of California, Los Angeles.

processinfo.head: Processing Information
processinfo.p: Digital materials were received on 5 optical discs. All digital file naming, organization, and arrangement created by Alan Mandell was retained.

Collections are processed to a variety of levels depending on the work necessary to make them usable, their perceived user interest and research value, availability of staff and resources, and competing priorities. Library Special Collections provides a standard level of preservation and access for all collections and, when time and resources permit, conducts more intensive processing. These materials have been arranged and described according to national and local standards and best practices.

We are committed to providing ethical, inclusive, and anti-racist description of the materials we steward, and to remediating existing description of our materials that contains language that may be offensive or cause harm. We invite you to submit feedback about how our collections are described, and how they could be described more accurately, by filling out the form located on our website: Report Problematic Content and Description in UCLA's library collections and archives.

bioghist.head: Biography/History
bioghist.p: Alan Mandell is an accomplished theater and film actor, theater manager, stage director, and producer. He is considered a foremost interpreter and scholar of Samuel Beckett's works. He was born "Albert" on December 27, 1927 to a Jewish family in Toronto, Canada, but officially changed his name to "Alan" in 1968. After serving as the Artistic Director of Theater '49 in Toronto in the early 1950s, he subsequently spent most of his working life in San Francisco, New York, and Los Angeles.

Mandell became involved with the San Francisco Actor's Workshop in 1954 while visiting his sister, and he helped the group's co-founders Jules Irving and Herbert Blau transform the Actor's Workshop into one of the first full-fledged regional theater companies in the United States. On November 19, 1957, the Workshop put on a historically significant performance of its production of Beckett's Waiting for Godot in San Quentin Prison, which was later discussed in Martin Esslin's influential Theatre of the Absurd (1961). Mandell, as Lucky, struck a chord with the prisoners, and he ended up co-founding the San Quentin Drama Workshop with inmate Rick Cluchey, who would go on to become an actor and playwright. During this period, Mandell also met his future wife, Elizabeth Heller, and the two were married in 1967.

When Irving and Blau were selected to run the Repertory Theatre at Lincoln Center in New York, they asked Mandell to join them in Manhattan as the company's manager. Blau left the Repertory after only a year, but Irving and Mandell remained through 1973. In the mid-1970s, Mandell moved west and joined the Los Angeles Actors' Theatre, which would transform into the Los Angeles Theatre Center in 1985. He served as a consulting director and actor, and he developed and oversaw the Poetry/Literary Series at the Center.

In addition to his time with these four major companies, Mandell worked on a wide range of seminal theatrical and film productions throughout his career, including the 1973 Broadway revival of A Streetcar Named Desire and J.C. Mitchell's 2001 film, Hedwig and the Angry Inch. Both he and Rick Cluchey collaborated directly with Beckett throughout the 1980s and continue to appear in productions of Beckett's plays.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Content
scopecontent.p: Materials in this collection document Mandell's professional career and include managerial records, scripts, signed monographs, photographs, clippings, and correspondence with many notable literary and theater figures, including Samuel Beckett. Contents may be of interest to scholars of literature, theater, performance studies, and arts management. The Beckett materials provide an unusually comprehensive portrait of the writer's intentions with respect to staging his work. The theater company records‚Äîwhich include financial documents, grant applications, interoffice communications, press, and programs‚Äîprovide insight into the process of balancing the practical and artistic goals of running a repertory. The files related to particular theater and film productions not connected to those companies are more commonplace; they consist primarily of contracts, fan-mail, rehearsal photographs, reviews, shooting schedules, and unmarked scripts. Digital materials (5 optical discs, 1 zip drive) primarily contain promotional images and audio/visual recordings of Mandell's work.

arrangement.head: Organization and Arrangement
arrangement.p: This collection has been arranged in the following series. Series 1 and 3 are arranged chronologically. Series 2 and 4 are arranged alphabetically. Series 5 is unordered.

relatedmaterial.head: Related Material
relatedmaterial.p: Actor's Workshop and Repertory Theatre of Lincoln Center records, 1947-1978 (bulk 1955-1973). Available at New York Public Library for the Performing Arts, Dorothy and Lewis B. Cullman Center. Billy Rose Theatre Division. Record number: b19817948.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Content
scopecontent.p: Contains appointment books, clippings, correspondence, and photographs related to Mandell's family and his early work in the theater.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Content
scopecontent.p: Scope and Content Note: Contains correspondence, notes, photographs, press, and published writings relating to individual literary and theater figures.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Content
scopecontent.p: Contains twenty-seven handwritten letters from Beckett to Mandell; Mandell's detailed rehearsal notes from productions in which he was directed by Beckett; scripts and monographs annotated by both Beckett and Mandell; and photographs from rehearsals and performances. In addition to the aesthetic value of the letters, these materials have substantial historical value for Beckett biographers and scholars of literature and drama in part because they capture the writer's goals as a director in a range of formats: annotations, correspondence, Mandell's notes, and photographs. As a contrast, a substantial portion of the Beckett materials are from productions with which Beckett himself was not directly involved, including the 2012 production of Waiting for Godot at the Mark Taper Forum in Los Angeles. Monographs were cataloged at the item level and can be found in UCLA Library's Online Catalog.

did.unittitle: Championing Beckett - Ruby Cohen and Her Legacy with Samuel Beckett
Journal of Beckett Studies (Numbers 11 and 12) and Note

scopecontent.head: Scope and Content
scopecontent.p: 14 postcard letters from Samuel Beckett in Paris to Alan Mandell in Los Angeles. Handwritten and signed ("Sam"). Dated or postmarked as follows.

1981 November 10 1982 February 6 1982 March 12 1982 March 16 1982 May 3 1982 September 15 1983 March 14 1983 May 9 1983 August 21 1983 December 28 1984 March 8 1984 March 21 1984 April 19 1984 December 13

scopecontent.head: Scope and Content
scopecontent.p: 13 postcard letters and 1 large envelope (dated 1987 March 19) from Samuel Beckett in Paris to Alan Mandell in Los Angeles and London. Handwritten and signed ("Sam"). Dated or postmarked as follows.

1985 April 9 1986 June 8 1986 September 12 1986 December 7 1987 February 9 1987 May 21 1987 September 1 (Beckett remarks on Mandell's misdating of his previous letter to Beckett.) 1987 November 28 1988 January 28 (Beckett appears to have misdated this postcard as "29.1.80.") 1988 March [19] 1988 April 14 1988 December 27 1989 July 27

scopecontent.head: Scope and Content
scopecontent.p: Three small notebooks of what appear to be Mandell's detailed handwritten notes about his experience traveling to London and working with Samuel Beckett during rehearsals. Mandell describes the rehearsals and Beckett's instructions in great detail. Folder also includes additional materials.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Content
scopecontent.p: Contains materials by and about a wide range of individuals involved in the theater, the literary arts, and Mandell's life. Includes substantial correspondence with Jules Irving, Herbert Blau, and Rick Cluchey, and minor correspondence with many figures, including Harold Pinter, Lawrence Ferlinghetti, and Gary Snyder.

did.unittitle: Literary Stages Los Angeles (Samuel Beckett Materials)
Miller, Arthur. Timebends: A Life. New York: Grove Press, 1987.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Content
scopecontent.p: Contains two letters from Daniel Selznick to Mandell that were inserted into Mandell's copy of Daniel's father's biography, Showman: The Life of David O. Selznick by David Thompson (Box 17). The first note is handwritten and from 1952. The second note is from June 18, 2011, and was written by Daniel as if he were Alan Mandell apologizing to "Danny." Mandell explains in an attached note, "This letter was written by Daniel Selznick. He sent it to me to chastise me for not thanking him for the theater tickets. I did thank him. He has a hearing problem, among other problems."

did.unittitle: Thomson, David. Showman: The Life of David O. Selznick. New York: Alfred A. Knopf, 1992.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Content
scopecontent.p: Contains materials relating to the management of four different theater companies. Includes casts lists, correspondence, financial records, photographs, production schedules, press, programs, and more.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Content
scopecontent.p: Scope and Content Note: Contains materials relating to both individual productions and the management of the Workshop as a whole. Includes documents relating to both the historic performance of Waiting for Godot in San Quentin Prison on November 19, 1957, and Jules Irving and Herbert Blau's controversial decision to leave the Workshop in 1965.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Content
scopecontent.p: Scope and Content Note: Contains records relating to the management of the Repertory and the productions put on by it in the late 1960s and early 1970s. Of particular interest for scholars of performances studies and race are the documents relating to the discrimination suit filed by a group of Asian-American actors against the Repertory (referred to as the "Oriental Actors" case). These include Jules Irving's internal memos about the case, lists of minority employees, a transcript of critic Clive Barnes's testimony, and the final decision of the New York Division of Human Rights in favor of the Repertory.

Subseries 3.4: The Los Angeles Actors' Theatre (1975-1985) and The Los Angeles Theatre Center (1985-1991)

scopecontent.head: Scope and Content
scopecontent.p: Contains records relating to the management of the Los Angeles Actors' Theatre and the Los Angeles Theater Center, particular theatrical productions, and the popular Poetry/Literary Series initiated and overseen by Mandell. The poetry materials may be of special interest to scholars interested in supplementing the existing scholarship on breakthrough readings and festivals with descriptions of the role played by regular reading series in the dissemination of the art.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Content
scopecontent.p: Contains contracts, correspondence, notes, photographs, press, programs, productions schedules, and scripts related to specific theater and film productions, including the 1973 Broadway revival of A Streetcar Named Desire produced by Mandell, the 2006-2007 production of Twelve Angry Men, Hedwig and the Angry Inch (2001) and Shortbus (2006) by J.C. Mitchell, and A Serious Man (2009) by Ethan and Joel Cohen.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Content
scopecontent.p: Contains various audiovisual recordings and an audio box set of Samuel Beckett's Three Novels (2006). Includes readings by Beckett and The Impossible Itself (2010), a documentary by Jacob Adams about the San Quentin performance of Waiting for Godot.

phystech.head: Physical Characteristics and Technical Requirements
phystech.p: Contains eight DVDs, an 18-CD box set of Samuel Beckett's Three Novels (2006), five additional CDs, and six audiocassettes, and two audio reels.
SERIES CONTAINS DIGITAL MATERIALS: Special equipment or further processing may be required for viewing. To access digital materials you must notify the reference desk in advance of your visit.
